dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GEORGE SIMMONS, 42, sits in a giant living room watching television on a 70-inch flat screen TV. He looks bored an empty. After a few beats he pauses the TV, and picks up t phone.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (on the phone) Hey, it's George Simmons, I'm coming in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shots of George doing stand up on stage at a comedy club. The place adores him. We see quick images of him after th show interacting with people. He is clearly a very famous comedian.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George has sex with a girl in her early twenties.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George sits back down, the thrill of his performance is g he is bored and alone again. He hits play on his TV and begins watching his show from the same spot it was at bef

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GEORGE wakes up in a large, clean, modern house. He is al alone. We get the feeling that he hired someone to decora his house. It is very nice, but doesn't seem personal to at all. It feels new, with all the gadgets, but a little cold. On the kitchen table is a stack of scripts he is supposed to read.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George hits balls in his home batting cage. Then we see h driving golf balls inside there. In the background we see his modern, space ship looking house. It is enormous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George walks into a fancy, steam-filled shower.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George drives his large black Mercedes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George gets out of his car and walks towards the tower. T COLLEGE STUDENTS walk over.

dialogues.speaker: COLLEGE STUDENT
dialogues.text: Hey George, can I get a picture with you?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Sure buddy. Let's do it. One of the college students put his arm around George whi the other takes the picture.

dialogues.speaker: COLLEGE STUDENT
dialogues.text: Can I get one?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Yeah bud. They take the picture.

dialogues.speaker: COLLEGE STUDENT
dialogues.text: You're the man. We love all your movies, even the last one.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Thanks. Tell your friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George sits in the doctor's office staring at the photos the doctor with his beautiful young children. DOCTOR STEV enters and sits down. He takes a deep breath.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I like those lunestas. They really put me to sleep without giving me the sleeping pill hangover I get from the restorils. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE, (COIN ' D)
dialogues.text: (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I try not to take them too often. Just when I know I have to get up early.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR STEVENS
dialogues.text: George there are some irregularities in your blood work... George's face turns white. He knows what this means. The doctor keeps talking but the sound keeps coming in and ou it is now all a jumble of words.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE'S POV
dialogues.text: We see photos of the doctor's family, his graduation certificates, files of other cases, odd doctor's office a a picture of him skiing with his family. He keeps talking but now we hear nothing. MUSIC UP - "MY SHIT's FUCKED UP" BY WARREN ZEVON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George walks down the stairs towards the parking lot in a daze. An ASIAN GIRL and her MOTHER and BROTHER see him an start screaming.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: Oh my God. Can you take a picture with me?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Yeah, sure. She puts her arm around him. Her little brother jumps in too.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: Thanks. You are the funniest.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Thanks, pal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George drives home. We hear the voice of his doctor in hi head.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR STEVENS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: It's a rare blood disorder. In the family of Hodgkins disease. We really don't have a treatment for it. There are things we can try. They're all very experimental in nature.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I don't understand what this means.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR STEVENS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I think you need to hope for the best and prepare for the worst. Is there someone who can help you get your affairs in order?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: IRA, a 25-year-old, works at the deli counter, along with CHUCK, a large, sweet-looking 45-year-old deli counter li and GAIL, a very skinny, very old, straight-talking, humorless woman in her fifties. Ira is in the middle of a very long conversation with a middle-aged WOMAN.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: Is the turkey organic?

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: Yes, ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: Well what does organic mean?

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: It means there's no additives or preservatives and it's hormone free.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: Are there additives or preservatives in the food they feed the turkey?

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: I don't know ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: I heard that because turkeys are fatty birds, mercury gets stuck in their fat. My daughter-in-law, she ate turkey and then she had a miscarriage.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: I haven't heard about that. But I may not be informed enough to comment.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: Well, you're not a doctor, so you shouldn't comment.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: You are correct, I am not a doctor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ira and Chuck are preparing trays of food.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: You should come see me do stand-up tonight at the Comedy and Magic Club.

dialogues.speaker: CHUCK
dialogues.text: I can't go through that again, man, that was painful.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: That was five months ago. I've gotten a lot better.

dialogues.speaker: CHUCK
dialogues.text: They pay you yet?

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: Nah, not there. I just hang out and hope somebody doesn't show.

dialogues.speaker: CHUCK
dialogues.text: Wow, is there anyway for you to.be lower in show business? I don't know if you could even say you're in show business. Why don't you just fucking settle down and enjoy this gig? This is a sweet situation. The money's good, you've got health insurance.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: Dude, I know you like it here but if I have to work here another year I would kill myself.

dialogues.speaker: CHUCK
dialogues.text: Really? In that case, when we bury you does it have to be in some kind of Jew cemetery? Next to Al Jolson or some shit?

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: Just come. I need the support.

dialogues.speaker: CHUCK
dialogues.text: No way. I'm funnier than you. And I'm not even that funny. I would go if I was paying to see me.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: I'll pay your cover charge.

dialogues.speaker: CHUCK
dialogues.text: Okay, well you better be good, because I'm bringing a date.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: Laughter's the ultimate lubricant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An Otis Redding song is playing as George walks around hi house in a daze, not sure how to process this. He doesn't call anybody. There's nobody in sight. We see images of h thinking about the unthinkable and the life he's lead. He sits in his office, surrounded by photos of himself at difference ages. It builds to a sequence of him going through stacks of old photos and watching videos of himse reviewing his life, trying to make sense of what it all meant. We see clips of his good movies and his last bad movie. On the wall is a poster of a buddy film which show him and another famous comedian. ON-SCREEN -- home video of George at college. George is hanging out with his friends. They are acting goofy, havi the time of their lives. George looks very young, skinny, and carefree. Life has never been better. They play a ridiculous drinking game and laugh uproariously.

ANOTHER IMAGE - We see a very young George performing sta up on Late Night with David Letterman. He's so young and naive, he seems like a completely different person. ANGLE ON George watching silently. He has no idea what to make of this journey of his.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ira sits with one of his roommates, LEO, who is also an aspiring comedian. They sit across from each other, kicki around joke ideas they have, trying to write new ones. We see an entire pitch session play out. Ira's joke pitches are all over the place. He clearly has figured out what his stage persona is yet.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: I was thinking about doing something about how I'm not good looking and I'm not bad looking. I'm just good looking enough that if I had a good personality, it could put me over the top. If that was the case.

dialogues.speaker: LEO
dialogues.text: Yeah, something about how the uglier you are, the better the personality you need. And the hotter you are, the stupider you can be.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: I had a joke once about how you never see incredibly hot, blonde, homeless women. Because someone will always take care of that kind of woman. That woman could be the dumbest person on earth and she will survive in this world.

dialogues.speaker: LEO
dialogues.text: Maybe something like... you can be hot and stupid and survive in the world. And you can be smart and ugly and survive in the world. The people who have trouble are the stupid, ugly people.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: That could work.

dialogues.speaker: LEO
dialogues.text: Let me keep that one, because I thought of most of it.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: That's not cool. I came up with the concept! What do you got? Let's work on what you have.

dialogues.speaker: LEO
dialogues.text: I've got nothing in the notebook. I got drunk last night. But I need material, because I just got spots at the Improv. Budd saw me and approved me. I'm in.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: How could they make you a regular? I got turned down twice.

dialogues.speaker: LEO
dialogues.text: Sorry, man. They're only going to let in one chubby, caustic Jew, so I think you're fucked. Their other roommate, MARK, walks in, waves a check at th

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Hey, dudes. You see this check that I got from my TV show for 25,000 an episode? There was another one of these on the kitchen counter. Did you see it?

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: No we didn't see it. Just don't leave those things laying around.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: I wouldn't leave it around if they didn't give me so many. They give it to me every episode.

dialogues.speaker: LEO
dialogues.text: Don't throw it in our face that you're on a shitty show.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: I wouldn't, if it was a shitty show and not what Time magazine called "insightful and delightful."

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: I thought you were moving out.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: I decided I like it here. Living with you guys keeps me grounded. I don't want to be the guy living in the house on the hill. Even though I could afford it. Hey, I saw that girl comic you like who lives upstairs. I invited her in. She's here.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: She's in our apartment? I've never even talked to her. I just gave her quarters at the washing machine.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: You were right, she is pretty mousy and sexy. You gotta talk to her.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: I need time. I have a three-month plan.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: I'll give you ten days for your three-month plan, then I am going to fuck her. You can't just leave that laying around. Starting right now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark is talking to DAISY, an alternative-feeling, dark-ha girl in her early twenties. His television show is on the TV.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: The thing about working on a sitcom is it's 22 weeks a year, so I can do stand-up the rest of the year. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: MARK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But now people want to see me because they see me on a TV show, so I am kind of a draw. Have you seen the show?

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: I don't own a TV.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Well I think you can download it to an iPod. Ira walks in.

dialogues.speaker: MARK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hey Ira, this is Daisy.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: how's it going?

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: Nice to meet you. I think I gave you quarters once. Ira walks over to the kitchen area, takes out a paper cup He pours some orange juice without looking and the paper falls over and spills all over the counter. Mark looks horrified.

dialogues.speaker: IRA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (nervously joking) Don't worry, I'll just lick it off the counter. Nobody laughs. Ira starts wiping up the OJ with a rag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leo is on stage, performing his act, doing well. ANGLE ON Ira watching, both amused and jealous. A MAGICIA and the EMCEE walks over to him.

dialogues.speaker: EMCEE
dialogues.text: Schneider didn't show up so, you can do ten minutes after Leo.

dialogues.speaker: MAGICIAN
dialogues.text: Don't go long because I have to load pigeons into my suit. I have to let them out or they'll die. I'm not fucking around. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: MAGICIAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So when you get the light, don't go long. You've got one minute. ANGLE ON Leo on stage, doing a few more jokes. A MANAGER walks over to Ira.

dialogues.speaker: MANAGER
dialogues.text: Hey man. George Simmons just got here, he wants to go up. You're bumped. We'll put you on after George.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: Well how long is he going to do?

dialogues.speaker: MANAGER
dialogues.text: I don't know. Last night he did five minutes. Last week he did an hour. fie'il do what he wants to do.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: Well what about the magician? He just loaded his pigeons. He said I have to get off in ten minutes.

dialogues.speaker: MANAGER
dialogues.text: I'll have him unload the pigeons. Just be ready. Leo finishes his set to huge applause then comes off stag

dialogues.speaker: LEO
dialogues.text: That was good, right? Some of the new stuff worked.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: I just got bumped by George Simmons.

dialogues.speaker: LEO
dialogues.text: Are you serious? Shit - I've got a spot at the Improv, I cant hang out, damn.

dialogues.speaker: EMCEE
dialogues.text: A lot of times you hear about going to a comedy club and someone exciting shows up. I won't lie to you, that usually never happens. But tonight it is happening. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: EMCEE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ladies and gentleman, you know him from [movie credits to go here] George Simmons? George walks on stage. The place goes crazy. He does some of his normal routine and the audience laughs and is very appreciative. As George continues his act, it starts getting darker and darker until he is talking about death and the lack of meaning in it all.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Ah life. What does it mean? sometimes life makes perfect sense. And then you `come'.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: He's killing the crowd. Jesus, I can't follow this shit. After completely losing the crowd, and some minor confrontations with audience members, he exits the stage.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Life isn't all about laughs. Crazy shit happens. You've got to be nice to each other. You never know what's going to happen. Ira passes George as he heads onto the stage.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Sorry I sucked it up out there. At least they are well rested for you. Ira, takes the stage. He starts trying to do his act, but is unsure of himself and unable to figure out how to take weird energy of the room and spin it to his advantage. He basically bombs. We reveal Chuck and his date watching, looking miserable.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: I'm not good looking. I'm not bad looking. I'm just in the middle. And if I had a personality that was Jut good enough, it would put me over the edge. The joke fails. We reveal George also watching him bomb, amused by his struggle. He sees something he likes in Ira

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ira walks to his car. In the spot next to him is an enorm Suburban SUV parked in a spot meant for compact cars. It so close to Ira's car that it isn't possible to open the door. He hears some banging and odd wails from in the car Ira knocks on the window. We see that George is sitting i his car in a world of pain. He's clearly been crying. The knock startles him. He turns to Ira.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: Sorry, man. I didn't mean to disturb you. I just can't open my door. There's no room.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Oh I'm sorry. Let me pull out. George pulls the car back ten feet.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (calling to Ira) Hey man, you had some funny shit tonight.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: Thanks!

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Man, that audience hated you. They really did not like you. They liked your buddy, who looked exactly like you but was funnier. Man, that's going to haunt you. You're going to wake up in six months and think about this night.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: Well, I'll probably bomb worse tomorrow and forget about this one.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I'm just fucking with you. You had some funny jokes in there. Good writing.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: Well, obviously, I'm a... you know...I grew up on your shit, man. George just stares at him.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Alright, pal. Don't worry. Only two hundred people saw that tonight. I'll see you later. George pulls out, turns the car around, and as he passes Ira, he steers his car as if he's going to run him down, starts screaming...

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You're gonna die!!! I'm gonna kill you! Then he smiles at Ira and drives off. Ira smiles. This is the greatest thing that's ever happened to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FULL SCREEN COMPUTER: We see a comedy short made by Leo. It's very funny.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: Holy shit, you got seven hundred thousand hits in four days.

dialogues.speaker: LEO
dialogues.text: They put it on the main page at YouTube and it exploded. Which would be awesome if someone would pay me. The phone rings.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Hey, is this Ira?

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: Yeah. Who is this?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: It's George.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: Oh my gosh. Hey, how is it going?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I thought you and Leo were pretty funny last night and I have to do this corporate gig for Apple computers in a couple of days and I thought you guys could write me some jokes.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: Definitely. What kind of jokes? Leo passes by in the background. We see Ira decide not to include him in this job offer.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I don't know, about computers and shit. I could mainly do my act but they like it if you talk about them a little.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: No problem. Where do you want me to send em?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: What is your email? I will send you my fax and email and all that.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: It's a...irasexiraГѓВ‚Г‚В®gmail.com.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (long silence) I almost just changed my mind. You got to change that.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: Ok.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Today. Seriously. Ok. Later. Ira hangs up and turns to his friends.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: That was George Simmons. He wants me to write jokes for him.

dialogues.speaker: LEO
dialogues.text: Holy shit. That is awesome. You are so lucky.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Are you gonna get to meet him?

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: I don't know, but he is gonna send me his email address.

dialogues.speaker: LEO
dialogues.text: We are gonna have his email address? I have to send him the link to my short.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: Easy. Let me get in there a little more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ira is writing jokes. The camera follows the letters bein typed on the computer screen as he types. "Always erase your web history. I had a girlfriend hit history and see eleven hundred porn sites that I visited an hour." Jonah sticks his head in.

dialogues.speaker: LEO
dialogues.text: I got one, but you have to tell him its mine. The best thing about Leopard is it lets you watch a porno, write a porno, shoot a porno, and order a porno all at the same time. And you guys made that possible. We see QUICK IMAGES of him typing and printing. He is writing an enormous amount of jokes. Way more than George will ever need. Writing, typing, re-writing in pen, then typing, etc. Ira hesitates, then hits send.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ira is asleep. The clock says noon. The phone rings. He answers it, groggy.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: There's some funny shit in here. Not a bad ratio of good jokes to shit.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: Thanks man. I just want to give you a lot of choices.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Too many choices. I don't like reading that much. I need like ten good jokes. I'm a little mad you made me read that many to get to ten. But thanks for doing it.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: Oh, it was fun to try to write in your voice. I spent the whole night pretending I was you.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: So you cried yourself to sleep? (ALT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you whacked off three times last night? Don't worry, I'll get you some money. Is five hundred good?

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: Yeah! That'll work.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I'm leaving at four tomorrow to go to the gig. You want to come check it out, see if your shit works?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE-UP on their curtains, as they wait for George to pu up.

dialogues.speaker: LEO
dialogues.text: Can we go outside and meet him?

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: No you can't. Because then we look like fans.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Maybe he's seen my show.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: He doesn't watch your show. You're show is for eight-year-olds. It's a family show, he doesn't watch that shit.

dialogues.speaker: LEO
dialogues.text: I'll just go outside and pretend I'-,n washing my car. The Limo pulls up outside.

dialogues.speaker: LEO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Holy shit. I feel like my little girl is going to the prom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door opens, Ira gets in.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: How you doing, you ready for this?

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: Yeah, this'll be fun.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I think I'm going to have you go on before me to warn them up.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: You don't have to do that. What if I bomb?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Hey, if you bomb, they'll just be more excited to see me. They'll be so glad your not on stage any more. Then if you do well, they'll be ready for me. Either way, you're helpful.

dialogues.speaker: I/E PRIVATE JET
dialogues.text: The limo pulls up to a private jet. Ira is shocked. A moment later they're picking up speed to take off. Geor seems really relaxed. Nothing registers that the jet is going faster and faster and taking off.
As they're having a conversation, Ira seems really freake out. Ira pretends he isn't.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I like this joke about watching porn and making porn all at the same time. That was a good one.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: (turning white from

dialogues.speaker: TAKEOFF
dialogues.text: Oh good. Yeah, I thought you'd like that one. I was really happy with that one.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: You want something to eat? I had them bring Chinese on the plane. Ira's eyes widen. He likes this way of life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DAVE from Apple is walking George and Ira into the room. It's a giant room that holds a thousand people at banquet tables. ON STAGE - Sting is finishing up a set. This is a huge corporate event.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Okay, what do you want them to say when he introduces you? Do you have any credits he should mention?

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: (long beat) Uh...credits? I don't really have any credits. Maybe you could just say I've been working on Apples for so long, my first one weighed more than I did. Nobody laughs.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: And just say he's a friend of mine, and I think he's funny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ira's on stage doing his act. He tells two jokes that don do very well. And then he panics and does the joke about jerking off and shooting a movie all at the same time. ANGLE ON George, shaking his head, amused that he panicke and did one of the jokes he sold to him. CUT TO the wings of the stage. Ira's walking off stage.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: What the fuck is that? You did three of the jokes that you wrote for me.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: I panicked. They just wanted jokes about computers.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: That's why I hired you, to write jokes about computers. Ira takes out the long list of jokes he's written.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: But there's a lot more. The first three on this page. You didn't think they would work, but I think they will. You should just try them.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: They better kill, I'm getting paid a hundred thousand dollars for this.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: Are you serious? ANGLE ON DAVE on stage.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Ladies and gentleman, George Simmons. George does a few Apple jokes that do kill, and then he segues into his normal act. When he wants to be, he is a great performer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George and Ira sit on the plane, on the way back.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: We'll be on the ground in a half hour. Want to go to a bar? Do something fun?

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: Sure. I like fun.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Here's a grand for the jokes and the gig. Even though you should be paying me after that. Ira's eyes widen.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Good job.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: That's the most money I've ever made doing anything in comedy.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Then this is an exciting moment.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: Well, I didn't make a hundred grand like you.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I feel nothing. I remember when a grand was the most exciting thing in the world. I'd go to Red Lobster and go nuts. Now it's just numbers in a bank account. Enjoy tonight. You made a thousand bucks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George and Ira enter. People are very excited to see Geor They give him a nice table. -- George and Ira talk to two women, MANDY and DAWN. They both seem really into George. Ira feels kind of left out.
-- George focuses on Mandy, flirting and preparing her to home with him. -- The other girl is now talking to a very uncomfortable She is not into it.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Hey, let's all go back to my house.

dialogues.speaker: MANDY
dialogues.text: Great!

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: (HOPEFUL)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, that sounds like a... nice idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Music is playing. Everybody is drinking. Mandy is doing some weird sort of sexy dance for George.

dialogues.speaker: MANDY
dialogues.text: This house is so big. It's bigger than the college I went to.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Oh there's a whole other wing that you wouldn't even know existed unless you went through this door.

dialogues.speaker: MANDY
dialogues.text: I want to see, I want to see. George and Mandy disappear. Ira and Dawn are left alone.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: You are very pretty.

dialogues.speaker: DAWN
dialogues.text: I have a boyfriend. Nothing is going to happen.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: I didn't say anything was going to happen. I just said you were pretty. How do you even know I wanted something to happen?

dialogues.speaker: DAWN
dialogues.text: I hope she doesn't take a long time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George is having sex with Mandy.

dialogues.speaker: MANDY
dialogues.text: I can't believe I'm having sex with Davey!

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: He can't believe he's having sex with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ira and Dawn are watching one of George's films. Neither looks very happy or comfortable. George enters.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Hey, Mandy thought you left, so she left.

dialogues.speaker: DAWN
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Sorry, that kind of stuff happens when you have a big house.

dialogues.speaker: DAWN
dialogues.text: Oh, well then I guess I better get going?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: You don't have to go. I'm just saying that she left. I think she left her purse in the other wing. Come with me, let's go get it. Ira watches this, astonished.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE, (CONT' D)
dialogues.text: Did Ira tell you I have a room with all the classic pinball machines and video games?

dialogues.speaker: DAWN
dialogues.text: That sounds awesome.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Yeah, I got Galaga. Let's go check it out.
George looks over his shoulder at Ira, as if to say, "A m gotta do what a man's gotta do."

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to Ira) Hey don't go, I'll be back in a second.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ira is now watching the end of the movie by himself. Geor sticks his head in.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: That girl left. You want to talk to me while I try to go to sleep. Ira doesn't know what to make of this.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: I guess so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George is in bed under the covers, comfortably laying on pillow. Ira sits in an easy chair located right next to t bed.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: Did you have sex with both of those girls?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I'm afraid I did. I'm sorry. It was just so clear that you were not going to get it done. I figured you wouldn't mind.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: That is crazy. That is super crazy.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: It was great. It was crazy great.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: How can that even happen? I guess I understand the first one, but why would the second one do it? You probably stink of the first girl.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Well, we took a steam shower together.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: she had never seen a steam shower before, I told her she should enjoy it.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: She wouldn't fool around with me because she said she had a boyfriend.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: She told me that too, but she says I was on her and her boyfriend's list of people she was allowed to screw. You'd be surprised how many women have me on that list.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: I should get going.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Just talk to me before I fall asleep. I'm weird. I don't like being alone. You should crash in one of the rooms. You're too drunk to drive home. I won't try to fuck you, I just fucked two women and I'm kind of done.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: I may have to whack it in your guest room.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Whack away, I don't give a shit. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, you were funny tonight. I could see how you could get good.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: Thanks. That was fun. It was rare that I get to play to more than twenty-five people. I've never played for a thousand. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: IRA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: it, s kind of easier, because even if two hundred like me, it sounds like a lot.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I do feel bad for you, because no matter how hard you try, you'll never be as funny as me.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: Why would you say that?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Did your dad crack you on the head when you were a kid?

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: That's why. My dad always seemed annoyed with me. He'd always crack me on the head. You would not see it coming. I spent my whole childhood trying to make my dad laugh so he wouldn't smack me. But he was an awesome guy. He was the coolest. He just got annoyed with me. Do you like your parents? They can't be that bad, because you're not that funny.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: They're bananas. And always broke. They got divorced ten years ago, but they both act like it just happened last week. They hate each other. They always put me in the middle of it. I always wanted them to say, "We don't want you to suffer through this, so we're just going to handle it ourselves." They never would do it. They would always make me feel their pain all the time. I would never do that for my kids. Because it's like they._`.re kids. And no matter how many times I tell them to leave me out of it, they never do. Ira notices that George is very close to falling asleep.

dialogues.speaker: IRA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'll let you crash.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: No, keep going. It's interesting. Tell me about your day job?

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: Alright. So... (knows he's a sleeping pill at this point) I work at a supermarket at the deli counter. I hate it, but the money's actually pretty good. Better than you'd think. But I'd rather do comedy full-time if I could. The camera pulls back as Ira continues to talk, and we be to HEAR George snoring, as Ira continues to talk anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George walks into the guest room, where Ira is sleeping.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Hey man, you want to make me breakfast?

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: okay.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Do you know how to cook anything?

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: Eggs.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Okay, let's have some eggs. While Ira is cooking, George takes a lot of pills.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: What are you doing, man? Are those vitamins?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: No. Medicine. I'm sick.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: What do you got?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I've got some crazy blood disease. They think I'm going to die in six months to a year. Some weird thing, almost nobody has it. All these are experimental.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: Are you fucking with me? That's not funny, man.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: No, I'm telling you the truth.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: I never heard that before. That would be a big deal.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I haven't told anybody yet. I don't think I'm going to.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: You're not going to tell anybody? You told me.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Well it's easier with you because I don't know you. I don't feel weird around you. I don't want to be treated like a guy who's going to die.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: I don't know, man. I don't think you want to go through this alone. I think you've got to tell people. Your family. Your friends.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Actually, the reason why I only told you is I need you to do me a favor.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: What? Anything, man.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I can't imagine suffering through the final stages of this. So...I was going to ask you if you would be willing...to euthanize me.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: What does that mean?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Kill me. I figured if I found someone that nobody knew that was a stranger, they could get away with it, and I wouldn't have to suffer. I got a gun that is untraceable. And a silencer. And I thought maybe tonight, I would take a bunch of sleeping pills, and when I slept you would put a bullet in my head.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: I can't do that!

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I'll give you fifty thousand dollars in cash. You'd be doing me a favor. It would be the kindest thing you could ever do for somebody.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: Fifty thousand dollars? Can I at least take a little time to think about it?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Holy shit, you would do it. You were literally thinking about doing it!

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: You're an asshole.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I'm an asshole, you were about to kill me. For fifty grand! That's not even a lot of money.

dialogues.speaker: IPA
dialogues.text: I just got nervous so I was delaying saying no.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: You basically just told me that you were willing to be a murderer. While you're cooking me eggs.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: That's not cool, man. You told me you're going to die and you want me to euthanize you. I almost had a heart attack.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Well, I actually am sick. And I'm not going to survive.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: Don't do this. My friends do this all the time. They trick me, and then they trick me again. I'm very gullible. Don't do it.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I'm not putting you on, man. Just don't tell anyone. I mean that. I don't want people to know about this. I don't want to feel weird. Ira nods okay.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: Are you religious? Does that give you any comfort?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Do you really think I'm going to sit here and have a theological conversation with you?

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Maybe later, Father Mulcahy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The three friends - Mark, Ira, Leo - smoke pot and have w they think is a deep conversation.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: That's so sad.

dialogues.speaker: LEO
dialogues.text: If it was me, I would tell everyone. Then everyone would kiss my ass. And take care of me. Tell me how much they love me. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: LEO
dialogues.text: Wipe my ass when I had to go to the bathroom. They'd be crying and sad, and that would make me feel really good.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: He doesn't want to be that guy. He picked up two girls at a bar. Then he had sex with his. And then he came out and had sex with mine.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: In front of you?

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: So being terminally ill makes you a cock-blacker?

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: No, what I'm saying is...He's so lost right now that he's hiding from the world. And he's trying to distract himself by doing stand-up and having sex with a lot of women. And he doesn't want anyone to know but me.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Why you?

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: Because he doesn't know me. So he doesn't give a shit.

dialogues.speaker: LEO
dialogues.text: That's kind of insulting.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: No, I think we had kind of an instant connection. The other roommate, JAY, walks by.

dialogues.speaker: JAY
dialogues.text: You fucked him?

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: Shut up, Jay. Jay keeps walking.

dialogues.speaker: IRA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I feel like he's crying out for help, and I can help him. He's made us so happy in our lives, this is our chance to do something from him during this time. There's a lot of wisdom we can take from this. What he's going through. We can apply it to our lives.

dialogues.speaker: LEO
dialogues.text: Like how to bang two chicks in the same night, even though you have a terminal disease?

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: No, what is life all about? What is important? How should we decide to live this precious life? REVEAL that Mark is crying.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Don't talk about this shit when we're high. It really freaks me out and it makes me sad and it scares me. I don't want to talk about this shit.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: That's why we should talk about it! You can't run from it, man. This could make us into better people. This is an opportunity.

dialogues.speaker: LEO
dialogues.text: I don't want to talk about this shit until I'm 80. I'm 24 years old.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: Well I'm going to fucking learn something. Mark cries even more.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: When my grandfather died, we were in a room with no windows. And they said he was dead. And there was a candle. And it started flickering like he was blowing it out. But there were no windows. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: MARK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We all thought that was him going to heaven.

dialogues.speaker: LEO
dialogues.text: You have to go through fire to get to heaven? That wasn't him going to heaven, that was him going to hell.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Fuck you guys. I was trying to open up. I'll never do it again. You're just being mean because I'm making twenty-five thousand dollars an episode.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George is bored, playing guitar. He picks up the phone, dials.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ira answers the phone.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Hey. You want to see if we can get on-stage somewhere?

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See quick moments of Ira on stage at the Improv doing a s Then George does a set, tears down the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George and a few of his friends are playing a famous rock song for fun. But they are very good. The music continues through the following sequence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George and Ira are eating with several famous comedians, shooting the shit, having a good time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George and Ira are waiting at the parking valet. The car pulls up. As they get in:

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I was thinking about it. I could throw you some money every week for coming up with new jokes for me. Maybe you can organize them in the computer, keep track of what I'm doing.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: Absolutely. What do you want to pay me? They close the doors, drive off.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I'll throw you $1500 a week.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: Okay, that could work. We can tell that this amount of money could change Ira's life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George and Ira are writing jokes. Ira keeps pitching premises/rough joke ideas that George instantly makes ten times better off the top of his head. (We shoot this proc for real with multiple cameras and try to catch lightning a bottle.)

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: I was thinking maybe you should do some material about what you're going through, being sick. There could be something really powerful, and it would mean a lot to people, that you would share that with them.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I'm just doing stand-up to have fun, forget about it on stage. There's nothing funny about that.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: It could be classic stuff. For the ages.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Fuck classic stuff. Idon't give a shit what people think of my shit when I'm dead. Why don't you wait till you're about to die and then you do a bit about it? I'll bet you're about-to-die shit will be funnier than my about-to-die shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George and Ira are doing sets again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George is making a phoney phone call on a speaker phone. listens.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (Grandmother voice) I ordered your Roast Beef. And normally it's delicious. But this time I paid a price!

dialogues.speaker: DELI MANAGER
dialogues.text: I'm very sorry ma'am. What if you come in and I give you a free sandwich?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (Grandmother voice) Well that's very nice of you. But I have one question for you. Can I get two sandwiches? George motions for Ira to do something.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: Grandma! Get off the fucking phone. Don't run up my fucking bill.
Ira starts slapping his hands together. George screams in pain.

dialogues.speaker: DELI MANAGER
dialogues.text: Ma'am! Are you okay?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (Grandmother voice) This is a family matter! He can hit me if he wants. He's my grandson, and I love him! Now may I give you my name, so you have it on file so I can get my free sandwich? K-A-C-A-H-A-K-R-E-K-K-U- C-T-A-R-S-U-T-A-R-G-M-S. Did you get that? Can you say it back to me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ira enters.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: George? George? He walks through the house, finds George in bed. For the first time he seems sick.

dialogues.speaker: IRA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Are you all right?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: No, I had a bad night last night. I was sweating though the sheets, couldn't stop. So I got up, watched half of a season of The Wire and then I slept till...what time is it now?

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: It's three in the afternoon.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I wanted to get up and do something. But I don't think I have it in me. I may just go back to bed.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: Well do you need anything?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Yeah, I need all sorts of things. But nothing you can get me. You should go up anyway. You were in a groove the other night, you don't want to get rusty.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: I. .I. .can't anyway. I'm doing the late shift at the deli counter.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Really? How long you gonna keep that job for? I'm paying you good money. What if someone you perform in front of goes into Ralph's and sees you cutting turkey?

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: I know, I just want to be safe, make sure I can pay my bills. I don't like to be nervous about that shit.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I wasn't like you. I had a different theory. You've got to spend money to make money. Nothing makes you work harder than being in debt. Maybe we should go buy a Corvette. That'll make you try to be funnier.

dialogues.speaker: CHUCK
dialogues.text: so how much notice are you giving me?

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: Notice? I'm not giving you any notice. I'm just quitting.

dialogues.speaker: CHUCK
dialogues.text: You're supposed to give notice. That's what people do.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: Why would I give you notice? I'm not trying to stay in Ralph's good graces. I'm not trying to preserve my good standing at Ralph's. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: IRA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'm just quitting. You don't quit and then keep working for two weeks.

dialogues.speaker: CHUCK
dialogues.text: Well I don't have enough people to cover all your shifts, now I gotta cover them.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: I wish I could help you, but I'll kill myself if I keep working here. It's not what I want to do. Maybe Gail can cover my shifts.

dialogues.speaker: CHUCK
dialogues.text: Gail can't work weekends, and my kid's birthday is this weekend. What am I supposed to do?

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: I don't know. Get someone to cover from a different Ralph's. There are thousands of them in Southern California. No one else can scoop macaroni into a bowl? I'm not the linchpin that keeps Ralph's from falling into chaos.

dialogues.speaker: CHUCK
dialogues.text: You're an asshole. You always thought you were slumming it here. Go tell your tucking fart jokes., Get the fuck out of here before I kick the shit out of you.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: You know what? I'm glad you said that, because I was about to tell you I could work this weekend. What's your problem? I didn't say anything bad about you, I just said I didn't want to work for Ralph's anymore. Chuck takes a step to Ira like he's going to hit him. Ira steps back a few feet.

dialogues.speaker: IRA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'll tell Dave. I'll tell Dave. I tried to do this politely. The thanks I get.
Ira walks out the store. As he walks out, he turns to a l (in her 40s) at the register.

dialogues.speaker: IRA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: See you, Phyllis. You're nice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ira sees Daisy walking out as he's walking into the apart complex. He takes a deep breath, then:

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: Hey, Daisy.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: Hey --

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: Ira.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: (she doesn't) I know.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: I was gonna try to hunt down tickets to see Wilco at the Greek Theatre. You want to come? Are you into them at all?

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: I would love to come. That would be amazing.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: Okay. I'll call you with the details. Hopefully I'll be able to get seats which will not require high-powered binoculars.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: I don't care where the seats are. I just like to close my eyes and listen to the music at concerts,

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: Perfect. Then I can play you their live album in my car and trick you into thinking we have front row seats. (laughing uncomfortably) That won't work. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: IRA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That wasn't funny at all. I'm gonna leave while I'm ahead right now. She smiles. He walks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ira walks into George's house.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: George? Ira walks into George's bedroom. He hears something, poke his head in. In the dark, he can barely see George making phoney calls himself. Ira listens for awhile, not sure what to make of this. George doesn't see him.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (speaking like an old

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: I was robbed! One second you're walking down the street with your Visa card, having a grand old time, and then you've got a fucking gun in your mouth!

dialogues.speaker: VISA LADY
dialogues.text: What's the number of the card, Ma'am?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I don't know! The thief has the card, why don't you ask the thief the number of the card! George hangs up the phone. He starts dialing.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (as a Texan) Ah yes, I came into your comedy club tonight and I was very offended by the performer. I did not pay good money to have the so- called "comedian" shake my wife's hand, then smell it and say, "Did you have fish for dinner?" That is not my idea of entertainment. Ira leaves the room, feeling like he's intruded on a priv moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George and Ira are eating.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: I was thinking you need to tell someone about your situation... your condition.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: No, no. IГѓВўГўВ‚В¬Г‚Вў don't want to do that.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: I feel like maybe you're holding everything in and I can understand why you don't want to deal with it because why would anyone want to deal with it. But I bet you have a lot of unfinished business with your friends. Wouldn't it make you feel a lot better to get your affairs in order? What do people do at this moment Don't they have to do stuff?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I don't want to do anything. I just want to be in the moment and live every day the best I can. As soon as I confront it with everybody, everything's changed and I can't get back.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: Everything has changed. At some point you're going to get really sick and you need your friends and family around you. I'm sure there's a lot of business, estate issues, I don't know. Maybe you'll feel better than if you just deal with everything. Where are your parents?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: P4y parents would drop dead if I told them what was happening. They're in their 80s. They don't have to go through this. I'll make sure they find out at the last possible second.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: Friends?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (BEAT)

dialogues.text: I don't feel sick at all, and it's scaring me. I feel like I'm just going to drop dead. Am I not going to feel bad at all, and then one day wake up dead? It's disconcerting.

dialogues.text: I don't want to get your hopes up. We put you on this experimental medication without much optimism, but as of right now I don't see any traces of the disease in your blood work. I don't want to speak too soon, but we may have beaten this thing.

dialogues.text: Ira's eyes are wide with shock.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: Oh my god, oh my god! Ira goes to hug George, but it's a very awkward moment. I really wants a happy hug, but George is instantly uncomfortable.

dialogues.speaker: TNT. OFFICE

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I really want to thank you for your help through this time.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Well, you didn't have to, and you were really there for me. I was thinking, maybe we should write a movie together.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I feel like I've learned a lot, and I wanna use this good place I'm in right now to do something really creative. I would pay you, certainly. I make, you know, about a million dollars to write a script. I can't give you half, but maybe one hundred, two hundred grand, but we'll figure it out.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: (what?) Yeah, we'll figure it out.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I thought a lot about my work when I was sick and I'm in sort of a strange place career-wise, because I'm normally the goofy, funny guy and I don't know if people are expecting a change from me. And I think people are expecting me to evolve, and it's important to evolve before they make a point of asking me why I'm not evolving.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Is that something they taught you at the deli. I'm not asking you for your advice, I just though we could start trying to come up with an idea.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: Well, I'm gonna start thinking. And...I'm really happy for you. Are you freaking out right now?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE, (CONT'D)

dialogues.text: And he thanked me for helping him, and I really think I was a help during this time. I'm not saying that's why he got better, but he definitely had good energy and I hear that helps your immune system.

dialogues.speaker: MOM

dialogues.speaker: IRA

dialogues.speaker: MOM

dialogues.speaker: IRA

dialogues.text: Your younger sister got accepted to Boston University but, as you know, your father and I aren't in the position to pay for it.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: So I have to? I just stopped working at a supermarket two weeks ago. I'm trying to create some financial stability for myself. The first time I make any real money, I can't just give it to her.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Well that's very selfish.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: Well you guys went on a cruise to Greece last year. Maybe you shouldn't have gone, and saved for her college education.

dialogues.speaker: MOM
dialogues.text: Oh, so after all we've done for you, we can't have any fun? We should never take a vacation?
