dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ira is performing on stage, doing his set. He's doing rea well. This theater crowd is very enthusiastic about being there and gives him the benefit of the doubt on most of h jokes. As he continues his set, he gets more confident an for the first time in the film, we think he has the poten to be a strong comic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laura is sitting in her seat by herself. Ira makes his wa across the aisle and sits down next to her.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Ira. Oh my gosh. You were so good.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: You seem surprised.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: I don't know, you seemed so nervous. But you were really solid all the way though, and your ending hunk really murdered.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: Thank you. Hopefully George won't be mad if I tired the audience out.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: I don't think he has anything to worry about. They always go crazy for him. Before he got famous, he used to bomb all the time. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: LAURA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And that's when I think he was the funniest. And now that everyone knows him, it's a little too easy for him, I think. No one was funnier when the audience hated him than George. He loved it.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: So you guys were dating right when he started doing well?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Yeah. But you always knew he was gonna do well. He had so much charisma. He would walk into a room and in ten minutes that whole room would be about him. Even before anyone knew who he was.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: Where did you meet him?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: I was the hat-check girl at the Improv. And I was acting. I used to do guest spots on all those shows, like Melrose Place, Beverly Hills 90210. I always played the bitch. I don't know why, but I was on the top of the bitch list.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: You don't seem like a bitch.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: That's because I was acting.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: Sounds like fun days.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: It was, for awhile. Reveal George in the wings trying to get a look at them f a distance.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: I don't know if you've heard, but it looks like George's medicine is working.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: IPA
dialogues.text: When George got sick they didn't think they had any medicine that would help, so they put him on experimental medicine. And the last time he went to the doctor they couldn't detect his blood disease. They think it might be gone. A moment as Laura takes this in.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Why didn't George tell me?

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: He just found out. He doesn't want to jinx it. He doesn't want people to get excited, and then have it come back again. The lights go down.

dialogues.speaker: ANNOUNCER, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Ladies and Gentlemen. Here's the man you came to see. George Simmons. The place EXPLODES.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: (JOKING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought everyone came to see me. George begins his act. He could not kill harder. Or look more healthy and charismatic. We can tell it is all a sho for Laura. Laura is completely thrown by this turn of events. The content of George's act is meant to portray him in a positive, sympathetic light to Laura. He talks about bein sick and the lessons he learned in a very dark, hilarious and also uplifting way. All of it is intended to make him look like he has grown up and become wiser, and someone y could trust and spend your life with.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laura is talking to George and Ira.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: I really don't know what to say. It's not like you weren't good before, but your act is so much more sophisticated, but just as funny. I've never seen you speak so honestly on stage before. You used to say these goofy jokes. It was really something, you know, and you should be really proud of yourself.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Thanks. A lot has happened. And at least I got some good jokes out of it.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Well, thanks for inviting me. I'm really glad I came.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Ira and I are driving out of town tomorrow, I thought maybe we could stop by your place on our way out. I want to see what the ranch looks like, and meet your husband.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: My husband is actually in China for another week, or so. He spends a lot of time there helping American businesses break into that market. So you won't meet him this time, but it would be great if you came by. That would be fun. I'll give you the tour.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Okay. We'll come by in the morning.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Okay. An awkward beat. Laura gives Ira a hug goodbye, then hugs George goodbye, trying to make it appear as if they have equal weight.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Bye. I'll see you then. She looks at Ira. As she exits--

dialogues.speaker: LAURA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You were good too.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: Why do we have to stop by there tomorrow? The drive is long enough as it is. George opens up his wallet, gives Ira a thousand dollars.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Here's your money for tonight. Good job.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: I'm excited to see her ranch. I hear it's delightful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ira and George are in a room that has two queen-sized bed They each lay on their bed in the dark.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: Why couldn't we have gotten two different rooms?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: What's the fun in that? You can go pay for your own room, I don't care.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: So, what happened with you and Laura? You seem to get along so well. Why did you cheat on her?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I was young, stupid... and I liked fucking girls. Why do you think I cheated? You would do it too if anyone would fuck you.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: How many times did you cheat on her?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Two or three times ...a week ...for a couple of years.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: Jesus.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: It was awful. There was even marriage talk. My parents didn't want me to do it because she wasn't Jewish. She was taking classes to convert, even. I mean, how cool is that? She was changing religions to be with me. She knew more about being a Jew than I did from those classes. She was so cute when she spoke Hebrew, it sounded so wrong. George says the Jewish grand prayer with a waspy accent.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And then one day, somebody told her, I don't know who. And that was that.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: Why do you want to go see her tomorrow? We could do something productive like get some writing done.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I like her. I love her. I miss her. I just want to spend a little time with her. I know nothing will come of it. I just miss being around her. A beat. George starts clicking through Video On--Demand a movies.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Anything looking good to you?

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: I don't want to watch adult movies with you.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: okay. You want to watch Juno?

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: Okay.
Juno begins playing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George and Ira drive up to the house. It's a large one-st house that is part of a ranch with a lot of land and a ho stable. They walk to the front door, ring the doorbell. George se a little nervous.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: You okay, buddy?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Yeah, of course I am. Laura opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Hi? We've been waiting for you. Come on in.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: This place is beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Thanks. We've been here for five years. I think I just finished decorating it. She leads them through the living room into a huge open kitchen. On the island, there is freshly squeezed lemonad chips and dip. She has over-prepared for their arrival.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: Can I live here?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: of course, you can clean the stables.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: You have horses?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Yes. Clarke, my husband, was a real city boy. But for some reason he loves horses. Of course I'm lef t to take care of them. But yes, we have three horses.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: That's crazy, owning a horse. I can't even keep a goldfish alive.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: All right, well, we're ready for the big tour. I want to see how you live. Suddenly, Laura's five-year-old daughter INGRID runs into room and she's pissed.

dialogues.speaker: INGRID
dialogues.text: Mom! You said you were coming back! We're playing American Idol, you're ruining the game! Ira is shocked to see that Laura has a child. This complicates a situation he already thought was getting to complicated.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: I'll come right up. This is my friend, George. And Ira.

dialogues.speaker: INGRID
dialogues.text: It's my turn to sing and you're supposed to be the judge and you're not in there and I'm very angry!

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: How old are you?

dialogues.speaker: INGRID
dialogues.text: Five. But I turn six very soon.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: Really? Because I thought you were like nine, about to turn ten.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: She's very pretty. (to Ingrid) I like your hair.

dialogues.speaker: INGRID
dialogues.text: I'm so sick of people telling me they like my hair. George is clearly not that good with kids.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Okay. I do not like your hair.

dialogues.speaker: INGRID
dialogues.text: Don't make fun of me.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: He's just joking Ingrid.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: My hair. I have curly hair too. Curly hair is the best.

dialogues.speaker: INGRID
dialogues.text: Last week my mom straightened it and it almost went to the floor.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: If you straighten my hair, I look crazy. I look like the killer from No Country for Old Men. Have you seen that movie? MABLE, Laura's ten-year-old daughter storms into the room

dialogues.speaker: MABLE
dialogues.text: You guys left me all alone in the playroom! If you're gonna leave I'm just gonna go talk on the webcam with Caroline.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Don't be rude. This is Ira and George.

dialogues.speaker: MABLE
dialogues.text: Oh, I know you. My mom watches your movies all the time. But most of them I'm not allowed to see. George smiles at Ira--Laura's a little busted.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Oh, really? Do you like them? Which one's your favorite?

dialogues.speaker: MABLE
dialogues.text: I don't know. I don't really like the ones I'm allowed to see, but I think I would like the ones I'm not allowed to see. But she says I cant' see them till I'm sixteen.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Sixteen? Just fast-forward past the bad parts.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: The whole thing is a bad part. George LAUGHS in a slightly flirty fashion with Laura. Ir getting uncomfortable with the subtext.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA, (CONT' D)
dialogues.text: C'mon, let's finish the game.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George, Ira, Laura, and Mable are sitting on the floor. Ingrid stands on a make-shift stage singing a Miley Cyrus song while wearing a feather boa and sunglasses and a red wig.

dialogues.speaker: INGRID
dialogues.text: (SINGS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've got the best of both worlds. Rock it out take it slow. And then you rock out the show! Everyone applauds for her.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Okay. Now it's time to see what the judges say. I thought you had a lot of energy, you're clearly gonna make it to the final four, and I love your outfit. What do you think, Randy?

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: Yo, dawg. That was the bomb. It was a little pitchy in places, but I dug it. I really dug it.

dialogues.speaker: MABLE
dialogues.text: .I'm Simon, and I thought it was horrible. I don't how you made it this far in the competition. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: MABLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I think Paula is drunk. You will never be American Idol.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Mable, stop it. Stop being mean to your sister. Say something nice.

dialogues.speaker: MABLE
dialogues.text: (ANNOYED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were good.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Okay, you're not Simon anymore. (to George) Simon, what did you think?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I can't believe I'm saying this, but I agree with Paula. I think you're the one to beat. They all applaud. Ira notices Laura looking at George wit admiring eyes that reek of more than friendship.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Okay Mable, you're up. Mable instantly starts gyrating in a manner that is not appropriate for a ten-year-old and singing the Fergie son "London Bridge."

dialogues.speaker: MABLE
dialogues.text: (SINGING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to go down like London, London.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: I told you not to do that. Simon, what do you think?

dialogues.speaker: INGRID
dialogues.text: She was horrible! She's a terrible singer! She's inappropriate!

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Okay, who's next? Randy?

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: I don't know, Dawg. It was a bad song choice. I'm not feeling it.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: My turn. Get ready to be blown away.
George gets up on stage.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (SINGING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take me down to the paradise city. Where the grass is green and the girls are pretty. Oh, won't you please take me home. (FASTER)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just an urchin livin' under the street, I'm a hard case that's tough to beat. I'm your charity case so buy me somethin' to eat. I'll pay you at another time! Take it to the end of the line!

dialogues.speaker: MABLE
dialogues.text: Boo!

dialogues.speaker: INGRID
dialogues.text: Boo!

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: What? It's Paradise City, by Guns and Roses.

dialogues.speaker: INGRID
dialogues.text: You sound like a girl!

dialogues.speaker: MABLE
dialogues.text: Vote him off!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laura sits on a ATV. George sits behind her. Ira is on another ATV with Ingrid sitting in front of him, as he steers. Mable rides a very small dirt bike.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: All right! Here we go. They start driving down a path that goes around the edge the ranch. George has his hands around Laura's waist as t drive. Ira looks over, concerned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laura shows them their horses, chickens, goats and ducks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laura points out a small pond and a fenced-in riding area Laura slows down and allows Ira, Mable and Ingrid to get ahead and turn a corner. Then she stops the ATV and turns around and kisses George. George looks surprised, but happy. Laura just stares at h trying to decide what she makes of him now. Then we hear O.S.

dialogues.speaker: MABLE, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Mom! Mom! Laura hits the gas and they continue the tour.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The kids are playing in the background as George, Laura a Ira talk.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Ira, Laura invited us to stay over for dinner.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: But it's like a seven, eight hour drive home. If we stay for dinner, we're not going to get home till like four in the morning. George stares at Ira for a beat, then --

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Don't worry, we'll figure it out. You have something to do in the morning?

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Then everything will be fine.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Me and George are gonna go to the supermarket and buy some food so I can cook dinner. You think you'll be okay watching the kids? It'll only take forty-five minutes.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: Sure. I'm great with kids. I was a camp counselor for five years. Camp Winadu. Kids love me. I'm like a human teddy bear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laura is driving through town. George sits in the passeng seat.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: This town is so small and adorable. It's like out of a Demi Moore movie.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Clarke's company is about forty- five minutes from here. This town seemed so perfect when we were looking for a house. There's no traffic, there's one coffee house, one bookstore, one market. No crime. But after you've lived her a few years you hunger for another coffee shop, a bigger bookstore, and a little crime. It gets so boring. And it's such a small town, God forbid you miss one of you kid's soccer games, they put the scarlet letter on you.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: it can't be that bad. You live on a pretty little ranch. You have horses, a duck. It must be a nice life.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: We used to have so much fun. I don't think I have that much fun anymore. I don't like who I'm turning into. Is the fun over? I have to get up every morning at six, drive my kids to school and then I have 6 hours before I have to pick them up. I have to yell at them to do their homework, be a taskmaster, then I make them dinner. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: LAURA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It takes an hour to shower them and put them to bed. And then it's 8:30 and I pass out. And it's great, but tuck. And when both kids are done with high school I'll be 49 years old, and then I'll have probably 6 very healthy years, then I'll kind of slow down and then I'll be an old woman. And that was it. And it's great, but fuck.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I couldn't believe you moved out of LA. You were getting some good jobs as an actress. You got to play the bitch on Melrose Place for awhile and make out with Andrew Shue. That was pretty good. Do you miss it?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Yes. Being a mom is very fulfilling, but there are other parts of me and every once in awhile I go a little crazy.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: How do you go crazy?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: I just get bored and depressed. And you know how my PMS is kind of out of control. This little boy hit Ingrid in school, and his mom acted like she didn't care at all, so I told her to fuck off. They both laugh.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Oh, that must have gotten ugly. How long did that stay awkward for?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: (JOKING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Always. That woman hates me. And I hate her. And now our kids really like each other, so it's really fucked up.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Maybe you weren't acting on Melrose Place.
She laughs.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Screw you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ira, Mable and Ingrid are making elaborate paper mache he As they do it, Ira is leading them in the type of song yo would sing at camp.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: And my husband cheated on me, said he did it once but I know because I learned from you, they do it once, they do it all the time. You either cheat or you don't.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: well I don't anymore. I haven't cheated on anybody since you. I haven't even been in a committed relationship since you, so it's impossible for me to have cheated.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: That's both flattering and deeply disturbing.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I thought a lot about you when I was sick, and I would do anything for another chance. I know it creates a mess, but I think it would be worth it. I think we both know it's what we should be doing. He kisses her.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: We can't go the supermarket.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Because people will see us.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: So? What's wrong with that?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Well it'll be weird because we're about to do something we shouldn't do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ira, Mable and Ingrid are outside at a table building hou out of Popsicle sticks.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: If you had an Exacto knife we could cut these sticks in half and make a chimney.

dialogues.speaker: MABLE
dialogues.text: (SADLY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When is George gonna die?

dialogues.speaker: INGRID
dialogues.text: George is gonna die?

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: Why would you say that?

dialogues.speaker: MABLE
dialogues.text: I heard my mom talking to her friend about it on the phone and crying.

dialogues.speaker: INGRID
dialogues.text: I don't want George to die.

dialogues.speaker: MABLE
dialogues.text: What do you care? You just met him.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: George is gonna be fine.

dialogues.speaker: MABLE
dialogues.text: They told me my grandfather wouldn't die, but he did.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: Here's the truth. George was really sick. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: IRA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But he went to the doctor and they found the right medicine and now he's better. And he's gonna live a long time. The kids buy it, and Ira seems relieved.

dialogues.speaker: MABLE
dialogues.text: I think my mom's in love with him. Ira looks doubly disturbed. He quickly goes back to his popsicle sticks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George and Laura park in the driveway, then sneak around back guest house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George and Laura enter the guest house, which has been tu into her husband's office/playroom/sports-viewing room. O the wall are six enormous flatscreen TVs. The room is als filled with sports memorabilia in Lucite cases and expens looking sports photography.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Does somebody in your family like sports? They start passionately making out, slamming into the flatscreens.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: I really never thought I was going to see you again. I grieved for you like you were dead. They continue to kiss. Suddenly she stops.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I can't do this.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Then let's not do it. She stares at him, trying to figure out what he's become- he a good guy or a bad guy?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: I gotta get back to the kids.

INT. LAtJRA'S RANCH - ENTRYWAY - DAY Laura and George are walking into the house. They are not holding any bags. They walk into the living room where Ir is making a Spongebob SquarePants puzzle on the floor wit Mable and Ingrid.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: You're back. That was quick.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: The town is beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: Where are the groceries?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: We decided ordering in might be a little more fun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone is sitting on the couch watching Ratatouille on television. They see car lights in the driveway.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Food's here! All right, everybody. Let's sit down at the kitchen table. Everyone gets up and heads toward the kitchen. Laura open the front door, George is a few steps behind her. A hands man of forty appears. This is not the pizza guy. It's CLARKS, Laura's husband.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Clarke, oh my gosh. What are you doing home?

dialogues.speaker: CLARKE
dialogues.text: The man I was supposed to have a meeting with had a heart attack, if you can believe that. So I decided to try and sneak home for a few days before my next set of meetings. George appears behind Laura, not knowing what he's gettin himself into.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Oh. Hello.

dialogues.speaker: CLARKE
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Oh, Clarke. George had a performance last night in town, which I went to, and him and his opening act, Ira, came by to say hello on their way out of town. There is an awkward moment, then Clarke smiles and gives George a compassionate look, the type of look you give a you think is dying.

dialogues.speaker: CLARKE
dialogues.text: It is really nice to meet you, George. Laura talks about you all the time, and we're obviously big fans of your movies.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Well, thank you. You've got a great family and a great home.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: I'm so glad you're home, honey. Laura gives Clarke a hug and a peck. Then Ira walks over.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: What's taking so long with the pizza? Before anyone can say anything the PIZZA DELIVERY GUY app in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: PIZZA DELIVERY GUY
dialogues.text: Hi. That'll be twenty-eight forty- seven, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone is seated for dinner, including the kids.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: (NERVOUSLY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is really great pizza. Thank you very much. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: IRA, (CCNT'D)
dialogues.text: It tastes just like New York pizza, which is so surprising because you can't get good pizza in Los Angeles, so you wouldn't think you could get it in Northern California. But this really tastes like New York pizza. A long pause.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Sounds like your business is going very well.

dialogues.speaker: CLARKE
dialogues.text: People never thought China would do this much business with us, you know, but it didn't seem like a risky proposition for me. They've got a billion people, we make all kinds of cool shit in America, they start finding out about it on the internet and what-not. Sooner or later they're gonna find a way to get our shit.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: He speaks Chinese. For real. Ingrid yells at something in Chinese.

dialogues.speaker: CLARKE
dialogues.text: You don't think they want new mobile phones? A new X-box? I'm trying to get access into North Korea, no shit. That situation could chance overnight. That is a huge market waiting to be tapped. It's already starting in Cuba.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: My friend backpacked across China and he caught some sort of virus or something from what he ate. He was sickforweeks. He still has it. It'sthekind of thing you can't getridof, you have it for the restofyour life, but it stays dormant.

dialogues.speaker: CLARKE
dialogues.text: So, George. How are you holding up?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Uh...I'm hanging in there.

dialogues.speaker: CLARKE
dialogues.text: How are you feeling?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: He's doing really well. He's been very strong.

dialogues.speaker: CLARKE
dialogues.text: It's a terrible situation. I'm so sorry.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I appreciate that.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: He's been fighting the good fight. His doctors are taking very good care of him. Ira can believe this conversation is happening.

dialogues.speaker: CLARKE
dialogues.text: You're a tougher man than me. I don't know how I could go about my day with that hanging over my head.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: It just makes you appreciate every moment. It brings things into focus, you suddenly realize what's important in life.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Does anybody want seconds? Or should I bring out the desert?

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: I'd love desert. What do you have? Do you have any ice cream or cake, or anything like that? I have a real big sweet tooth right now. Why don't we go into the kitchen and do an ice cream bar with kids right now? I've got a better idea, I make a really good milkshake. We should all go make milkshakes with the kids right now in the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: TNT. LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: Empty milkshakes litter the coffee table.

dialogues.speaker: CLARKE
dialogues.text: Do you know who might be able to help you? A Chinese doctor. Have you explored Eastern medicine at all?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Now's not the time to talk about this.

dialogues.speaker: CLARKE
dialogues.text: I'm trying to help the man.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: No, I haven't.

dialogues.speaker: CLARKE
dialogues.text: Hey. I'm the last guy who would buy into that shit, but it works.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: He really is the last guy who would buy into that shit.

dialogues.speaker: CLARKE
dialogues.text: Our country's only two hundred years old. The Chinese have been around for thousand of years figuring this shit out. How I got into it, I had acid ref lux and nothing was working and then this guy at work turned me onto a Chinese doctor and he gave me some herbs that tasted like dogshit, but they worked.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: (NERVOUSLY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I take herbs for my PMS. They really helped.

dialogues.speaker: MABLE
dialogues.text: Daddy, you've been cursing a lot. You owe me a dollar for every curse. I think you owe me fifty dollars.

dialogues.speaker: INGRID
dialogues.text: This conversation is scaring me. I don't want George to die.

dialogues.speaker: CLARKE
dialogues.text: You girls can go play in the other room. The Chinese have a completely different way of looking at health. They don't think doctors should attack the diseases in the body, they're all about trying to support the body and make it stronger, so the body can fight off the disease. It works. I've seen it. I wish I could find a way to mass-market Chinese medicine in this country. Someone's gonna do it and make a fuck-load of money. Because these people get old, really old. You can't kill these people.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: Either that or they're all young and they just look like shit. Clarke laughs.

dialogues.speaker: CLARKE
dialogues.text: This guy's funny. You should be opening up for this guy. Hey, who wants a drink?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone is taking a walk around the ranch. It is very pretty outside.

dialogues.speaker: CLARKE
dialogues.text: I'm going to retire in seven years. I'm done. I'm playing golf for the next fifty years. Work hard now, then get out. That's my plan. I'm putting in the time. Then I'm getting the fuck out. I don't like working. I will do it. I like what it gets me. But I don't like it.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: You ever see Laura act? She was quite an actress in her day.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: George, stop.

dialogues.speaker: CLARKE
dialogues.text: That's what I hear. Can't say I watched that much 'Melrose Place' back in the day. She keeps telling me to watch the videos but, you know, I was never a big 'Party of Five' fan.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Well, I also ran a theatre company. And it was down to me and Cameron Diaz for 'The Mask.' I sacrificed a lot for our family.

dialogues.speaker: CLARKE
dialogues.text: Okay, if you say so. (a beat) The Mask was a funny fucking movie. You know what other movie Cameron Diaz was great in? 'There's Something About Mary.' Laura looks livid at her husband's insensitivity and disrespect. They keep walking.

dialogues.speaker: CLARKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I love walking it off after a big meal.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: It's beautiful here at night.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: There's no pollution here like in LA so you can actually see the stars.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: They are beautiful, but we have to get going. We have a really long drive to get back to Los Angeles.

dialogues.speaker: CLARKE
dialogues.text: You can't leave now, you won't get back until daylight. You should crash in the guest house. I'm sure it not as fancy pants as where you live, George, but it's better than driving all night or crashing at a hotel. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: CLARKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And if you want to hang out tomorrow I just installed six flatscreens, we can watch all the football games we want. And dog- racing from Florida. There's a big game tomorrow. Ira, you must have played some ball in your day.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: No, I'm just big-boned.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: We probably should get some rest before the drive. All right, show us to our quarters, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George sleeps on the bed. Ira sleeps on a couch across th room. The door slowly opens, Laura enters wearing a bathr She walks to the bed and quietly slips under the covers, removing her bathrobe in the process. Without ever speaki she pulls the covers over both of them and begins to make love to him. George is surprised but not completely shock and goes along happily with it. ANGLE ON: Ira, he never wakes up.

dialogues.speaker: CLARKE
dialogues.text: You sure you can't stay?

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: We really do need to get back. I have to visit my mom. I can't miss it. It's her birthday. Everyone in my family is coming in from across the country for it. She's turning 65. It's very important we get back for it.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: That's too bad, I wish you could stay.

dialogues.speaker: CLARKE
dialogues.text: (very serious) I wish I could say I was gonna see you again, but I can't say that. His eyes start to mist up.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Clarke, don't. You don't need to do that.

dialogues.speaker: CLARKE
dialogues.text: You know what? I think I do need to do that. One thing I learned in China from some Buddhist friends of mine is it's important to have an open heart, to live in the moment, and to speak the truth to each other. So I'd like to say to you, George, that it was a great pleasure to meet someone who had such a big impact on my wife's life. I really like you. And wish we had more time to get to know each other. And I wish you a peaceful end to your journey. And another great journey on the other side of it. Clarke hugs George.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I really don't know what to say. I re- ally don't know what to say.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: That was beautiful, honey. Well let me walk them to the car. Ingrid walks over.

dialogues.speaker: INGRID
dialogues.text: Don't be sad. Ira told us that his medicine is working and he's not sick anymore.

dialogues.speaker: MABLE
dialogues.text: I think that was a secret. I don't think you were supposed to say that.

dialogues.speaker: CLARKE
dialogues.text: Mable, take Ingrid into the house.

dialogues.speaker: MABLE
dialogues.text: Can we watch another SpongeBob movie? Atlantis.Squarepantis?

dialogues.speaker: CLARKE
dialogues.text: Yes. Go into the house and watch a movie now! Mable and Ingrid walk back to the house.

dialogues.speaker: CLARKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What the fuck is going on around here? (to Laura) Is that true?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: I never said that he was still sick. He just took some medicine and it's looking better. You can't detect it in his blood, but it could come back.

dialogues.speaker: CLARKE
dialogues.text: Is it looking better? Or is he better? (to Ira) Is he sick anymore?

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: Well ...I don't how you define these things-I'm not... sure.

dialogues.speaker: CLARKE
dialogues.text: is something going on here? Are you getting your revenge on me while I'm away? I came clean with you, you can't come clean with me.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: You know what? I don't know what I want now.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: Oh shit. It's ON.

dialogues.speaker: CLARKE
dialogues.text: So this is what you want? Was he ever sick in the first place?

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: He was sick. He was very sick.

dialogues.speaker: CLARKE
dialogues.text: Because if this is what you want, I'll leave right now. I'm not going to play these games. I'm happy to leave. I'm not gonnna have you put me on the cross because I made some mistakes. You guys enjoy each other. I could give a fuck. If you need me, I'll be at my apartment in China. Clarke leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mable and Ingrid are asleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laura is alone in her room, crying. (she might be on the phone, talking honestly with a friend.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George lays on the bed. Ira is pacing around the room.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: What the fuck is going on? Did you guys do something?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: We had sex in Clarke's office.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Because I love her. She's the best thing that's ever happened to me.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: But she has two kids, she's married.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: She's miserable. He cheated on her.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: You cheated on her.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Yeah, but that was a long time ago. I've changed. You saw that douche bag. You don't think he's fucking geishas on every business trip?

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: He was trying to cure you with herbs. He seems like a great guy.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: This is none of your fucking business. Just stay out of it.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: I can't stay out of it. We took your car here. I have no way of leaving.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: This shit is deeper than you understand. People get divorced. People make mistakes and then they fix them. That's how life works. It's not a big deal. I know you're still sad because your parents got divorced. Well get the fuck over it. Call a fucking cab and go home.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: So what are we gonna do?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: You're gonna sleep in Clarke's office. I'm gonna go talk to Laura.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George walks into the room, discovers Laura on the comput going through papers. She is smoking a joint.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: On, there you are. I've been looking for you.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: I've been going through all the bank statements, trying to figure out which are in his name and which are in mine. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: LAURA, (CONT-C)
dialogues.text: Almost all the accounts are in his name. I wonder if he did that on purpose.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Are you smoking a joint?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Yeah. My best friend Nancy grows this stuff on a hill by her house. You want some?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: No, that stuff makes me paranoid.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Not me. It makes me feel sharper, Some people get tired, I get more energy, more clear.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: What's happening?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: What's happening? Whatever we want to happen is gonna happen now. I'm free. I'm fucking free. Laura gets up, kisses him.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We're free.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (NERVOUSLY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, we're free. They start kissing again. She starts to moan loudly.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Not so loud, your kids are sleeping.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: A tank could roll through this place, it wouldn't wake them up. They kiss some more. She moans louder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ira calls Daisy on the phone, in a panic about what is happening.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: (on phone) Hey, Daisy. It's Ira.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Oh. Ira. What's going on?

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: I just wanted to talk to you because I'm in the middle of a terrible situation and I don't have anyone I can talk about it with. My friends are all mad at me and George is kind of losing his mind.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: You can tell me, what is it?

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: Look, I know you think I have the moral code of some guy from the 50s like Dwight Eisenhower, but I'm with George and he's hitting on his ex-girlfriend who's married now and has kids and I don't know what to do. I'm kind of freaking out. I think I'm having a panic attack.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Well don't have a panic attack, that's not going to help anything.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: Well telling me to not have a panic attack is not going to stop it.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: (screaming at the top of her lungs)

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: Haha, very funny.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Seriously, what's going on?

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: Well I guess they dated like ten years ago...
Ira and Daisy begin to have a bonding conversation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laura, George, Ira, Mable and Ingrid are happily cooking eating breakfast. They look like a happy, strange kid of family.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Numerous images of them horse-back riding. Ira looks terrified.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are all fishing, feeding ducks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They pick lemons out of a tree.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are riding ATVs while their dogs chase them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The kids are climbing a tree. Laura is spotting them. George pulls Ira aside.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (EXHAUSTED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ, what time is it already?

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: It's 10:15 in the morning.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Oh my god. Really? I mean, this is fun, but I don't know how much I can take. Hopefully they'll take a nap at some point. I want to take a nap.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: They don't look that tired. The kids are yelling and screaming and clearly have eight more hours in them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George, Laura, Ira, and the kids are seated at a table. T kids are coloring with crayons.

dialogues.speaker: MABLE
dialogues.text: Look what I did. I want this hung up on the wall. She shows them the picture, which is clearly not appropri for the wall: a picture of herself choking and dying.

dialogues.speaker: MABLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The food here made me sick.

dialogues.speaker: INGRID
dialogues.text: Mama, I have to go to the bathroom. Come wipe my butt.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: I have to talk to them for a minute. Mable, go wipe your sister's butt.

dialogues.speaker: MABLE
dialogues.text: She can do it. She's almost six. That's weird. Ingrid and Mable walk off together.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: I wet the bed til I was eleven. It wasn't even a mental thing. I just got relaxed when I was asleep.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: I spoke to Clarke. He's going to fly back to China tonight. I was thinking about driving to the airport and meeting him there and telling him that when he comes back, he should find another place to live.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: That's great. Are you okay doing that?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Yes. It's what I want. I just need to figure out when we would move down to LA. It might be better to let the kids finish out the school year because I have to apply to the private schools in LA, and I don't know if I missed the deadline. Then I'd have to look into the charter schools. Sometimes these private schools, if you give them a donation, they let your kids in. Maybe you can stay up here for part of the year if I can't make it happen.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Sure. If I'm not shooting a movie, or on tour or something, that would be great. Laura leans in and kisses George. George is not big on public displays of affection. He kisses back, but you can tell that he's very uncomfortable. They hear the kids headed back to the table and quickly separate.

dialogues.speaker: MABLE
dialogues.text: I made her wipe her own butt.

dialogues.speaker: INGRID
dialogues.text: I did it, but I don't know if I did a good job. (to George) Look at what I drew. I drew a picture of you. Look? Show Mama. George holds it up. It is a picture of several people.

dialogues.speaker: INGRID, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That's you. That's George. That's Mommy. And Daddy. And me. And Mable. That's all of us. We see the picture, and it is everybody holding hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George and Ira are walking around a very small bookstore.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: This is a small bookstore. They've only got one Philip Roth book. Didn't he write like fifty books?

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: So when are we going to go home? You're not talking at all about when we're going to go home.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: She's going to talk to Clarke tonight, and then she's going to make a plan. We've got to get over that hurdle.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: Are you okay with everything? This is happening pretty fast.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: This is exactly what I wanted.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I mean, she's cool, right?

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: She's nice. I don't really know her very well.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: She was kind of cooler when I knew her back in the day. She's still hot, but she was crazy hot back then. Her attitude has changed a bit. With the kids and all. Back then she was really sexy, and all about fucking. I know she's busy with her life now, but it is a little different.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: Yeah, well when you have two kids and a husband, and horses and ducks, it's not all about fucking. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: IRA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That's just the hormones of youth. I'm all about fucking. But I don't expect to be when I get older. I'll be occasionally about fucking, which is normal. The fact that you're all about fucking now is the weird thing.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Well hopefully everything will work out. If it doesn't, it just wasn't meant to be.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: What does that mean?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: It means I'm going to give it a shot. I'm excited, but I'm not going to really know if it works until we're in it. I hope I'm just not in love with the person she used to be.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: She's about to leave her husband for good. She has two kids. You're not sure this is going to work?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: There's no way to ever be sure that anything's going to work! I couldn't live up here. She wants me to live up here. I don't think I can do it. Maybe a couple of weeks a year.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: Well, she'll live with you.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Do you think she means that she's going to bring the kids too?

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: Of course. What else would she do?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I don't know, don't some men get custody of the kids? Or they split the custody? I like the kids, but I've never lived with kids before. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The young one's kind of cute, but I don't think I can stand the old one full time. There's too much going on there. But I could definitely tolerate the young one. She's cute. Maybe they can split kids. Maybe Clarke will take the annoying one. Ira just stares at him, not sure what to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George kisses Laura, and then she gets in her car.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: I'll be back in an hour and a half, tops. And then it all begins.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Okay, call me if you need any backup.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: I love you.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (really uncomfortable) I.. . love you. The car drives off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ira is on the floor with the kids. He watches the headlig of Laura's car disappear down the driveway. George walks back into the room.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Okay, I'm going to go into the other room and watch some TV.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: You don't want to hang with the kids?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Nah, I was going to watch four hockey games at once. I've never done that.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: okay, but I've got to run out and grab some cigarettes.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: But you don't smoke.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: I never smoked in front of you because you were sick. But I do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ira drives in a panic.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: Holy shit, holy shit. Where's the fucking airport around here? Ira tries to figure out how to work the navigation system a panic. He can't make it work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George is watching the kids. He is not good with them, so is very weird.

dialogues.speaker: INGRID, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: George! Help! George jumps up and runs to her. She is in the bathroom sitting on the toilet.

dialogues.speaker: INGRID, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Can you wipe my butt?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Don't you know how to do it?

dialogues.speaker: INGRID
dialogues.text: I don't do it good.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (RELUCTANTLY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ira is still messing with the navigation system. He final gets frustrated and punches it.
Ira yells to someone on the street.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: How do you get to the fucking airport?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George calls Ira, gets voice mail.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Where are you, where are you? You have to come back here. I need your help. I don't know how to do this. He walks back to where the kids are. They are watching tv All around the room are family pictures. He is beginning feel bad about what is happening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laura gets to check-in, looks around. She does not see Clarke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George is sitting at the kitchen table. Mable walks over.

dialogues.speaker: MABLE
dialogues.text: I think my mom and dad are getting a divorce. I don't want my parents to get divorced. All my friends' parents are divorced, and they're not happy.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Why would you say that?

dialogues.speaker: MABLE
dialogues.text: I heard my mom talking to her friend. I listened through the wall. She was looking for a lawyer. He cheated on her. What does cheating mean? That he's going to marry someone else? Why don't they just try harder?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laura looks for Clarke at the news stand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George is on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Laura, it's George. Come back to the house. Maybe you shouldn't do it. Maybe it's too early for this. Call the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laura walks into the airport lounge. She sees Clarke. She looks at him for a moment, then heads over to him with determination.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ira parks in the no-standing zone. He gets out and starts walking into the airport. His phone rings, he answers. It George.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Where are you?

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: I'm getting cigarettes.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: You've been gone for forty minutes.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: I got lost. I don't know this town.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Well come back. I don't know how to take care of these kids, I'm not a camp counselor like you. These kids are on to me. The older one's too intense. She's troubled. She's like Damien, from the Omen. I need help.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: Ok, I'll hurry back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ira runs around the airport, looking for Laura and Clarke

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laura is talking to Clarke, emotional. Clarke is crying.

dialogues.speaker: CLARKS
dialogues.text: I'm so sorry. This only happened because of me. It's all my fault. I made you feel terrible. I made you feel unsafe in our relationship. I'm so sorry. Please forgive me. Ira stands there, staring at them.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: I'm sorry too. I love you so much. It was just a flirtation. It never went anywhere. It's just after you cheated on me, I felt so alone. And you were gone so often that I felt like our life doesn't work.

dialogues.speaker: CLARKE
dialogues.text: Then I have to make a change. I'll stop most of the traveling. There's nothing more important than you and the kids. Ira starts to turn to sneak away. Clarke sees him.

dialogues.speaker: CLARKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ira! What's going on? What are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: Oh, I'm just headed back to Los Angeles. I've got some spots at the Improv I've got to do this weekend.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: (under her breath) Oh, fuck.

dialogues.speaker: CLARKE
dialogues.text: You're headed back to Los Angeles? Then why are you at the International terminal?

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: This is the International terminal? I'm so confused, I've never been to this airport before.

dialogues.speaker: CLARKE
dialogues.text: Yeah, this is the Air China First Class Lounge. REVEAL that everyone else in the lounge is Chinese.

dialogues.speaker: CLARKE, (COIN' D)
dialogues.text: What the fuck is going on? What the fuck is going on, Laura?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: I don't know what to say.

dialogues.speaker: CLARKE
dialogues.text: Tel- me the truth ! Just tell me the tri.t_h.;_

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: I came here to tell you that I wanted you to move out when you came home. But I realized this was a mistake, so I didn't say it. Please don't hold that against me. We've worked everything out. Everything is fine.

dialogues.speaker: CLARKE
dialogues.text: Who's watching the kids? Who's watching the fucking kids?

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: An adult is watching them.

dialogues.speaker: CLARKE
dialogues.text: Is George watching our fucking kids? I will kill him. Clarke runs off.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: What the hell happened?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Who the fuck are you? Get the fuck out of my life! You and George have to get the fuck out of my life. You are ruining everything!

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: Uh oh. Ira runs out of the lounge. Laura runs out also.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George with the kids. Oblivious to what is happening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ira comes back out, his car is about to be towed.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: No, no, no! I'm here. I'm here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clarke drives home, pissed off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laura drives home, quickly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ira drives, in a panic, on his cell phone. The phone goes through to George's voice mail.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: George! Clarke is coming back to the house. He knows everything! I'm coming to get you. Be at the end of the driveway. No! Be at the next driveway over! To the north!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clarke arrives at the house. He sees George sitting with the kids.

dialogues.speaker: CLARKE
dialogues.text: (angry-to Mable and

dialogues.speaker: INGRID
dialogues.text: Can you take it into the family fun room?

dialogues.speaker: MABLE
dialogues.text: Are you two going to fight?

dialogues.speaker: CLARKE
dialogues.text: Ye s.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George and Clarke walk outside. Clarke puts up his fists, ready to fight.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: She's not happy. Clarke punches George in the face then kicks him martial style.

dialogues.speaker: CLARKE
dialogues.text: No one who's married is fucking happy. Leave us alone! You fucked up. You fucked it up with her a long time ago. Let it go or I will kill you. I will literally kill you till you're fucking dead. That disease didn't kill you. But I will kill you.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: You shouldn't joke about my disease. That was very serious. Very scary. Clarke punches him several times, but they are more like martial arts hits.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What the hell is that? Ira arrives. George starts yelling at Ira.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Don't jump in. Whatever you do, don't jump in. I don't want your help!

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: You said you were getting cigarettes then you ran to the airport to stop her. What kind of friend are you?

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: I am a good friend because this entire situation is crazy. You are out of control.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I didn't deserve what you did to me. You betrayed me !

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: When I got there, she was already kissing him. I never even had a chance to stop it. I didn't get to do anything!

dialogues.speaker: CLARKE
dialogues.text: Don't pretend you're fucking mad at each other, just to distract me so I won't beat your ass. Clarke pushes George.

dialogues.speaker: CLARKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You're gonna come to my house? You're gonna come to my fucking house? You have to get your own life. Leave us the fuck alone.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Don't hit me! I've been sick! They don't know. The medicine is working now, but I'm still sick. Clarke punches George.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to Ira) What are you doing? I said to jump in!

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: You told me not to jump in.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: That's what "don't jump in" means. It means "jump in." Help me! Ira steps in. Clarke hits him hard, then kicks him.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You're a terrible fighter.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: I know, that's why I became a comedian, because everyone used to beat me up! George runs at Clarke who cracks him in the head hard, sending him to the floor. Then Ira takes a run at him and Clarke kicks Ira in the face twice, with both feet. Laura runs into the middle of the scene.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Laura, tell Clarke to stop!

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Clarke, please don't do this.

dialogues.speaker: CLARKE
dialogues.text: Don't tell me what I can and can not do.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Laura, tell him. Tell him you want to be with me now. Laura doesn't answer.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Laura?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Why did you have to come here and confuse me? Everything was fine before you came here. Now everything is all screwed up.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Laura, what's it going to be? Are you going with him, or are you going with me? Laura looks at Clarke.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: With him.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Don't do this.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: You fucked up my life. And now I fucked up yours. But just a little. Probably just for a day. She walks back into the house.

dialogues.speaker: CLARKE
dialogues.text: Hit the road before I put you through another round.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: You cheated on her too!

dialogues.speaker: CLARKE
dialogues.text: Yeah, but we're married. We're going to work through this shit. You should have waited until you were married to cheat. It buys you another chance. Clarke punches George. Ira is on the ground. He doesn't g up.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: She told me I was the love of her life. And she loves me more than she loves you!

dialogues.speaker: CLARKE
dialogues.text: When she said that, did she think you were dying?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Yeah!

dialogues.speaker: CLARKE
dialogues.text: Too bad you had to 'Live and find out it wasn't true. Leave my fucking family alone! Clarke punches him. George gets a punch in but it doesn't hurt Clarke. Clarke punches him again.

dialogues.speaker: CLARKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I can do this all night.
Clarke hits George again. Ira leaps on Clarke and now all three are on the ground rolling around, arms flailing.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (to Ira) Stop Ira, you're hitting me too. Mable and Ingrid appear outside.

dialogues.speaker: MABLE
dialogues.text: What are you guys doing?

dialogues.speaker: INGRID
dialogues.text: What's happening? The three look at the kids and instantly feel awful.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: We're just playing that's all.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: We're wrestling. It's fun.

dialogues.speaker: CLARKS
dialogues.text: Boys like to wrestle just like girls. They all start wrestling some more, but this time it is f playful. They give each other noogies, and tickle each ot so the kids won't be scared. A little blood runs off of George's face.

dialogues.speaker: INGRID
dialogues.text: Are you bleeding?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: No. We were just painting. I got some paint on my cheek.

dialogues.speaker: CLARKE
dialogues.text: Come on girls. Let's go inside. Mable and Ingrid run inside. Clarke turns to George.

dialogues.speaker: CLARKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You know what sucks about this? I like your movies and now I can't watch them anymore. Clarke walks away, then walks back.

dialogues.speaker: CLARKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. That was mean. Through ail of this, I want you to know something. I'm glad that you're not sick, and I understand. And I forgive you. Clarke goes inside.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: That was meaner than him punching you. That is a demented motherfucker. George punches Ira in the face. Ira fires back two punche at George's face and he stumbles back.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: None of you fuckers can hurt me. George pauses, then leaps onto Ira and they roll on the ground for a moment. Ira makes his-way free and gets up.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: Get the hell off of me you psycho.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Drive me home.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: How are you gonna get home then?

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: Fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They drive in silence for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: You are the most self involved person I have ever met.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Oh yeah?

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: No matter what the situation, no matter how many laughs or how many women you get you will never be happy. You're always going to be miserable. You are a bottomless pit. A bottomless wound.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: What about you? You are just a lackey. Who are you to judge me? You tried to screw me over, after all I. have done for you.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: I am not responsible for you. You wanted me to sit back and destroy this woman's life? Help you cheat on her? You put me in a terrible position. I don't give a fuck, go fuck yourself.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Lacky.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: You made me the tacky? I'm not a lacky, it's a job.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: It's not a job, you're a tacky. You're not even that fucking funny. This gets Ira very mad.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: Who cares? If being funny means being like you, I rather be a little less funny.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Mission accomplished.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: You're the only person I know who learned nothing from a near-death experience! You actually went backwards. All it did was it brought out what a prick you are, brought everything bad to the surface. I liked you better when I was sure you were gonna die.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I'm not going anywhere!

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: Everything is about you. You don't even know where I live. You've never asked me one question about my life. How much can one person talk about himself ? You never ask me shit about anything!

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Who are you to fucking judge anyone? You're not my friend, you just want my money. You just want to get your foot in the door.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: Fuck your money. Fuck you. This has all been a huge mistake.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Wake me when we get home. George climbs in the back seat and tries to go to bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Music up: Ted Hawkins' song "Strange Conversation." Ira drives George home in the dark. Neither one speaks. We see images of different cities going by the window. Ir thinks about all he's been through and the challenges ahe

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ira pulls up to his apartment.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: okay, I'm getting out. You have to drive yourself home. I'm getting out here.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Why didn't you drive me to my house?

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: Because then I'd still have your car.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: You'll drop it off later.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: There is no later! I'm not going to ever talk to you again. So I don't want your car.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: So that's how it's going to be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George enters. There is an enormous pile of stuff to do o his dining room table. Several stacks of scripts. One pil has a big post-it note that says: "READ THESE!"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George lies alone in bed, alone. Eyes wide open. It's really bright in his room. George hits a button. The shades automatically close. The room goes dark. Now he's in the dark with his eyes open. He turns on the to go to sleep. It's the Today show. It's really happy an morning-themed. The piece on the Today show is very subur "How to Clean Up Clutter."

dialogues.speaker: ANCHORWOMAN, (ON TV)
dialogues.text: You know, when you've got a big family, and you've got a lot of clutter...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ira is talking to Leo.

dialogues.speaker: LEO
dialogues.text: We rented out your room to Jay. But you can crash on the couch if you want.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: Oh man, you got jerked off on that couch.

dialogues.speaker: JONAH
dialogues.text: I fucking didn't cum on the couch. Just sleep on it for a month, and then we'll find some excuse to boot Jay out.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: Thanks. I'm sorry, I lost my way for a while.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George reads one from a large pack of scripts. A few page in, he clearly doesn't like it. He puts it down, picks up another one. The large stack is clearly the ones he doesn't like.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ira writes at a table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George walks out of a store. A beautiful woman tries to c him up, but he lets her know he i.s"busy and has to go. H walks off. She looks disappointed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ira talks to Daisy. They seem to be getting along well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daisy is performing on stage. She gets off and heads over Ira.

dialogues.speaker: I HA
dialogues.text: That was great. She kisses him.

dialogues.speaker: DAISY
dialogues.text: Thanks. The MANAGER walks over.

dialogues.speaker: MANAGER
dialogues.text: Hey Ira, Federman got in a car accident. Do you want to take his spot? George walks over with a young comedian of about Ira's ag This young man has clearly taken his place.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Hey, how's it going?

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: Hey George.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: This is Randy. He's funny, you'd like his stuff. It's smart.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: I'm sure I would. I look forward to seeing it. Are you going on tonight?

dialogues.speaker: RANDY
dialogues.text: I hope so.

dialogues.speaker: MANAGER
dialogues.text: (to George) Do you want to go up? Ira was gonna take Federman's spot, but we can get you up if you want to?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: No, that's ok. I don't want to take Ira's spot. I'm just gonna hang out tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ira is introduced. He walks onto the stage. We see George walk to the very back corner of the club and sit down at table by himself. On stage Ira does his act. He is much more comfortable th we have ever seen him on stage before. He is no longer searching for his comic identity. He has found a way to b himself on stage, and tells jokes which are more personal than we have seen before. Not everything kills, but when something eats it he does seem thrown. Sometimes he seems amused.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: He watches from the back of the room. At first he does no laugh, but then slowly starts laughing--but more at the things Ira does in between jokes. We can tell that he is proud of Ira and misses him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ira is back behind the counter, working at the Deli with Chuck and Gail. He doesn't look too unhappy to be there.

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE CUSTOMER
dialogues.text: Is the potato salad fresh?

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: I made it myself this morning.

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE CUSTOMER
dialogues.text: Is it good?

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: I stake my reputation on it.

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE CUSTOMER
dialogues.text: Okay. Give me a quart.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: Mrs. Gail, this fine woman would like a quarf'of potato salad. The woman moves to the other side of the counter. We reve George standing there, holding his ticket.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Do you have any turkey that's hormone-free?

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: Yes we do.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: So this is where you work.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: Back in the saddle.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I thought we were writing a screenplay.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: Well, you're not a very good writing partner.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Or any kind of partner. You want to make me a turkey sandwich and talk to me? They give you breaks around here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a small seating area in the supermarket where pe eat food at the deli counter. George and Ira sit across f each other.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: In my travels, I have learned a lot about Asia and Buddhism. And I would like to be in the moment now with you, and to tell you how sorry I am, and how much I have appreciated your friendship. And even if we are not friends in the future, I wish you well on your journey. Ira laughs.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: That guy was a douche-bag.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: But also kind of cool. It's a very weird combination.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: He was going to heal you with those herbs, man. You get sick again, you should call that guy.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I think most of what you said to me was true. And I really am sorry. I think I'm still not very healthy...in my brain.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: It's all right, man. You've been through a lot.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Well, I appreciate you trying to help me. Even though it was kind of an impossible task.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: Is everything going okay? How are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I am not doing well, but things have certainly been worse. So, I will be fine. (THEN)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were good the other night. I hear you're getting regular spots now.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: I'm actually going up tonight.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Really? Any new jokes you're working on?

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: Yeah, I've been trying to get off my ass and do some writing.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: What do you got? Ira is surprised to hear him ask this, since he has never asked this before.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: I was thinking about doing a bit about how I'm not very good looking, but I'm not bad looking, but I'm just good-looking enough that if I had a good personality, it might put me over the top.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: You should do something about how, when you date a girl, and you feel really good and she likes you, and then you see pictures of all her ex- boyfriends, and they're all really goofy-looking guys, and it's not that you're good looking, it's just that in this psychotic girl's eyes, you're good looking?

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: And how all of her boyfriends look like Lou Costello.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Why don't you say Dom Deluise? it's a more current reference.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: More current? What year was Cannonball Run, 1978?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Okay, okay. What else you got?

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: I was going to talk about how I haven't had sex in so long, that I can't even remember my previous sexual experiences so I can masturbate to them.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: You should say, now when I masturbate, I have to think about the last time I masturbated.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: That's a good one. You can write.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: You know, I always wanted to be part of the comedy field. As the camera pulls back, George continues to pitch Ira j for his act, the first selfless act we've seen him commit the entire film. As their friendship rekindles, we...
